utterance: I don't believe they 've been fed.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Why, of course not; Aaron can't do everything.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Where are Simon and Johnny Bapter and the rest ?
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: I don't know what you are going to do, but I am going to find Drusilla. I have n't seen her since last night.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Aunt Big Sal, where is everybody ?
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Gone, honey, de Lord knows whar ; gone, honey, de Lord knows how.
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: Be afeard er any an' ev'ybody, honey, but don't be afeard er me ! Dodge frum one an' all, but don't dodge frum me. Not frum me ! No, my Lord !

utterance: Are they all gone ?
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Mighty nigh all, honey ; mighty nigh all un um. Dem what went wuz big fools, an' dem what stayed may be bigger ones, fer all I know. I 'd 'a' been gone myse'f, but I went 'roun' yander in de grave-yard, whar dey put dat cripple chile, an' sump'in belt me. I could n't go 'way an' leave 'im.

utterance: Why did they go ?
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Huntin' freedom. Yes, Lord, huntin' freedom ! I hope dey '11 fin' it; dat I does.
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: Grandfather says all the negroes are free now.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Did he say dat ? Did he say dat wid his own mouf ? Well, I thank my stars ! I 'm free, den 1 Me an' all de balance !
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: So Grandfather says.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Well, ef I 'm free, I better get up frum here an' go ter work. What does Marster want us ter do ? I 'm gwine up dar an' ax 'im.
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: Mammy walloped me kaze I won 't go off wid de balance un um. She say ef I stay here she got ter stay. I tell her I '11 do anything but dat ; I '11 tell lies, I '11 steal, but I won 't go off frum here ; dey got to kill me dead an' tote me. An' den mammy walloped me.

utterance: You need n't ter b'lieve a word er dat !
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: I tol' dat gal it would be better for we all ter go ef we wanter be free sho 'nuff, an' wid dat she fell on de flo' and 'gun to waller an' holler, tell I 'bleege to paddle 'er. I don't wanter go no wuss 'n she do, but dey say dat if we don't go 'way from whar we b'long at, we never is ter be free. Dat what de niggers on de nex' plantation say. I wuz born here, an' ef dis ain't my home, I dunner whar in de roun' worl' I got any.
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: Who cooked breakfast this morning ?
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Me. I know'd somebody had ter cook.
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: I thought so. The biscuits were mighty good.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: I dunner what come over me, but ef I set here wid my arm 'roun' you, an' you talkin' dat away, I '11 be boo-hooin' 'f o' I know myse'f . Git up frum dar, Drusilla, 'fo' I break yo' neck !
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: Nobody but old Fountain, old Fountain, as muddy as a hog, and harmless as a dove.

utterance: Whar is you been ?
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: Fur enough ter go no furder. I went a-huntin' freedom. De kin' I foun' will las' me a whet ; I promise you dat.

utterance: You doil 't tell me !

utterance: I does, an' I could tell yo' lots mo' dan dat ef I had time. Dey sot me ter work liftin' waggin wheels out er de quagmire, an' den a driver rap-jacketed me wid his whip — well, you see me here, don't you ? An' ef we 're bofe alive, you '11 see me here ter-morrow an' de day after.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: An' dey wa'n't no freedom dar ?
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: I won't say dat. Fer dem dat like de kin', 'twuz dar. Some mought like de change, but not me. I bless God fer what I seed, but I seed 'nufB. I went, an' I come.

utterance: Why n't you stop an' wash de mud off in de branch?
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: No, not me. Ter stop wuz ter stay. I know'd dey wuz a branch at home ; an' mo' dan dat, a spring. De idee wuz ter hurry back an' see e£ de natchel groun' had been left !

utterance: I b'lieve you ! I come mighty nigh gwine myself.
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: You 'd 'a' been sorry ! you 'd 'a' been sorry plum ter yo' dyin' day. You see me ?
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Well, I been dar. I been right wid um. You can't call it freedom atter you wade thoo dat mud an' water.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: All eyes open !
speaker: Johnny Bapter

utterance: AU eyes open ! I 'm It. Ten, ten, double-ten, forty-five, fifteen ! All eyes open ?

utterance: Whar you been ?

utterance: Kinder see-sawin' 'roun', foUerin' de ban's, an' keepin' ofE de boogers.

utterance: You did n't go wid um ?
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: No 'm ; not me ; I seed dey had plenty com p'ny. Mo' dan dat, I seed um hit ol' man Foun tain dar a whack er two, an' I 'lowed dat ez dey done come dis fur an' nobody ain't hurt um, maybe dey 'd git 'long all right. Dey ain't offer me no money fer ter go 'long and take keer un um. I wuz over dar at de camps las' night, an' I see niggers fightin' over scraps an' I hear chUlun cryin' fer bread after de lights done put out. So wid me, it wuz Howdy, and good-by, and I wish you mighty well. What mo' can a nigger do ?
speaker: Johnny Bapter

utterance: Dat 's so. Whar de bal ance er our folks ?
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: Oh, dey 11 come back in de due time. One '11 turn back at one branch, an' one at anudder ; an' dem what don't turn back at de branch will sho turn back at de river. Dey '11 all be home 'f o' de week 's out.
speaker: Johnny Bapter

utterance: What dey gwine do when dey come back ?
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: Work. Yes, Lord ! work frum sun-up ter sun-down.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: An' dey free too ?

utterance: Is dat so ?
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: Des like I tell you.
speaker: Johnny Bapter

utterance: I 've looked at it up an' down, an' it 's dis away — de man what eats honest bread is got to work. Dat what de Bible say ; maybe not in dem words.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: It sho is so. I '11 work aU day an' half de night, but I don' wanter hear no bugles blow.
speaker: Johnny Bapter

utterance: Wuz dey many er we-all wid dem ar white folks ?
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: Well 'um, I should sesso ! too many, lots too many ; more dan day 'U find rashuns fur, ef I ain't mighty much mis taken.

utterance: What dey all gwine 'long f er ?
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: Dey er feared ef dey stay at home dey won't be free. Now, how 'bout dat ?
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Why, grandfather says the negroes are free, whether they go or stay. Grandfather says he is mighty glad the black folks across the creek are free.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Dey been prayin' f er it 'long 'nuff.
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: We-all is free 'nuflf, but who gwine ter feed us ?
speaker: Johnny Bapter

utterance: Dat is so ; dat is sho one way fer ter look at it.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Well, I know one thing an' dat ain't two; I'd ruther starve right here, whar T been born at, dan starve way off in de woods whar nobody don't know me.
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: Well, well ! What's all this? Everything to do, and nobody to do it !

addressee: Jemimy, Big Sal, Old Fountain, Buster John, Sweetest Susan

utterance: Horses and mules to feed, hogs to call, sheep to salt, calves to take away from the cows. Well, well! I hear calls for meal, meat, syrup.

What do you suppose Mrs. Meadows thought when she saw that kind of a shadow staring at her through the water ?
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Well, grandfather says war is the worst thing that ever happened in the world, and I reckon it is.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: I don't believe you care whether he comes or not.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: I 'd keer mightily e£ he did come. I done been down dar long wid 'im once, and goodness knows I don't wanter resk it no mo'. Hit seem lak a skeery dream den, an' I don't want no sech dream ter come ter me no mo'. When folks git so dat water won't wet um, dey better be gwine off ter some yuther country.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: What 's the matter with you ?
speaker: Buster John

utterance: You better ax what de matter wid you-all. Dey ain't nothin' 't all de matter wid me. But I '11 say dis, when you-all see dat ar Mr. Fimblethinger — ever what his name is — you won't see me. Dat 's what ! I '11 set here wid you twel he pop outen de water, and den I '11 pop 'way f um here. Ef I 'm free, dat 's whar my freedom wiU shine out.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Well, you went once.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Yes, that 's me, Roby Ransom, corridor 1, room 9.
speaker: Roby Ransom

utterance: Who told you my name ?
speaker: Roby Ransom

utterance: I heard you call yourself Roby Ransom
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Well, you heard right for once.
speaker: Roby Ransom

utterance: Supper for the young-un ? Tooby shore ; fetch it. I did n't allow I 'd take in boarders when I started, an' I ain't got any too much vittles for myself.
speaker: Roby Ransom

utterance: There may be, but we are not sure about it, and we might make bad matters worse. There 's plainly some thing wrong about the man ; that much is certain ; but the child may be his, and it may be badly spoiled. No, it would be wrong to interfere with him ; I 've thought it all over.
speaker: the White -Haired Master

utterance: If you'll take my advice, you '11 make the negroes tie the man and lock him in the corn-crib until we find out something about him.
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: That would hardly be legal.
speaker: the White -Haired Master

utterance: Well, I don't think there is much law in the country at this time. If we knew he had stolen the child, what could you do with him ?
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: What you say is very true, truer even than you think it is. Still, there is no reason why we should be hasty and unjust.
speaker: the White -Haired Master

utterance: Where 's the baby ?
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: In the waggin. I wanted to take the imp out, but he would n't let me tetch him. Git him out, if you can.
speaker: Roby Ransom

utterance: Where are his shoes ?
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: He must er pulled 'em off and flung 'em away. Oh, he 's a livin' terror, he is. Don't you let him fool you.
speaker: Roby Ransom

utterance: Jemimy, go to the spring where the wagoner is camping, and tell Sweetest Susan and Drusilla to come straight to the house ; they should have been here long ago. Bring them with you.
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: Ef 'tain't down dar by de spring, I dunner whar 't is.
speaker: Johnny Bapter

utterance: Mist'iss, dey ain't no wagon dar !
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: Merciful heavens ! I told father to have the man tied and locked in the corn-crib, and now he has stolen my child ! Oh, what shall I do ?
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: An' he got Drusilla !
speaker: Jemimy

utterance: All ready, Master.

utterance: Are you going ?
speaker: the White -Haired Master

utterance: Yesj Master
speaker: Aaron

utterance: I 'm mighty glad of it. Where are the reins ?
speaker: the White -Haired Master

utterance: In the saddle ring ; I forgot to take 'em out.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: How do you drive without the lines ?
speaker: the White -Haired Master

utterance: He knows me, Master, and I know him
speaker: Aaron

utterance: What is the matter ?

speaker: Aaron

utterance: It was an army wagon. What has become o£ it ? It must have passed here. The first fork in the road is at Harmony Grove. We 11 go there.

speaker: Miss Elviry

utterance: Oh, it 's only me ! Take me out, please. Oh, this is not home ! Where am I ?

utterance: Oh, hush up. Spot ! now you 've started, you'll never stop.

utterance: What 's your name, honey ?
speaker: Miss Elviry

utterance: Is that you, Miss Elviry? Please take me out !
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Well, ef that ain't — Why! Well I know the end of the world ain't fur off now ! Susan Wyche, what are you doin' in this rig at this time of day, when by good rights you ought to be at home in bed ?

utterance: Take me out, please, Miss Elviry j and don't scold. I 'm going to run to the house as hard as I can.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Ef you are talkin' about your own house, you '11 have to do some extry hard runnin' ef you get there by dinner time. You '11 go into this house right here. 'T ain't so big an' fine, but the fire in there is just as warm, and your hands are like ice.
speaker: Miss Elviry

utterance: to make it feel like home,
speaker: Miss Elviry

utterance: Do your dressin' in your own room, we've got comp'ny this mornin'.
speaker: Miss Elviry

utterance: Comp'ny! Well, be jing'd ef they ain't afoot early ! That 's all I 've got to say, bejing'd ef 't ain't.

utterance: You know what it says in the Bible, Elviry ; fust war, and then signs and wonders. That 's what it says, bejinged ef 'tain't.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: He 's got to be a heap bigger than me ef I don't find out why he 's creepin' 'roun' a-stealin' children, and why he 's crope into my premises. Bejing'd ef he ain't.

utterance: Roby, you better come go with us, I reckm^ * said Mr. Bobs kindly, laying his hand on Ran som's shoulder ; come, now, you better go 'long wi' us.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: Ef 't ain't fine, it 's clean, thank goodness !
speaker: Miss Elviry

utterance: Please tate me down. Me want my bekkus. Me 'mell meat a-f'yin'.
speaker: Billy Biscuit

utterance: Did you ever, in all your born days !

utterance: You need n't be amazed at the blushin', she ain't been hugged afore, not sence — well, not sence I dunno when.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: May n't I keep him 'till his kinnery come ?
speaker: Miss Elviry

utterance: Less'n he begins for to blate an' squall at night.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: And we can come and see him sometimes.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Yes ; and when you come, fetch a lot of old clothes that used to belong to you an' your brother, ef your ma 's got any to spare.
speaker: Miss Elviry

utterance: Ef them mules has swallowed one bun dle of fodder, they 've walloped up a hunderd weight.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: Ef mammy don't hill me dis day, it 'U be kaze I 'm dead when I git dar.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: I ain't sleep a wink dis night, less'n you can call noddin' sleepin' ; not a wink ; an' when I does git holt er dat gal, I 'm gwineter make her wish she 'd 'a' stayed los'.

utterance: Just because she stayed with Sweetest Susan, I suppose.

utterance: You'd better thank the Lord, if you ever see her again.

utterance: I'll do dat, ma'am; I'll thank 'im on my bended knee ; an' f o' I git it onbent good, I '11 lay dat gal 'crost it ; an' when I git done wid 'er, she won't git in no mo' waggins — she won't git tuck off by nobody, not twel she 's done grown, er atter dey done put me on de coolin-board. utterance: All safe, all safe, Mistiss. They 're comin' in the buggy.

utterance: Get break fast — get breakfast ! they 're all hungry.

utterance: Howdy, mammy? Howdy, Mistiss ?

utterance: Well, I 'd have had one if I had been in the wagon. I would have guessed what was going to happen.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: How come you didn't? Why n't you guess we wuz gwine ter drop off to sleep ? An' why n't you stay down dar an' wake we-all up ? I don't like dish yer kinder guessin' what guesses when dey ain't no need er guessin'.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Huh! He'd 'a' gi' you sati'faction !
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: He 'd 'a' grabbed you an' rolled yo' head in one er dem blankets, an' ef dat ain't sati'fy you, he 'd 'a' gi' you sump'n else.

utterance: That 's aU you know about pistols.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: No needs ter know 'bout pistols, when you know 'bout folks. Why, honey, dat ar man would 'a' eat you up ef you dez so much ez bat yo' eye at 'im. Ain't I done see de way he chaw vittles, an' how he talk 'long wid hisse'f?
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: You 're mighty polite this morning, Johnny Bapter. What 's the mat ter with you ?
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Well, fust I bow ter you-all, an' den I bow ter dem ar waffles an' dat ar ham. I ain't see no waffles in so long dat I bleege ter bow at um. Dey may not know me, but I knows dem.
speaker: Johnny Bapter

utterance:
I ain't no ways greedy, An' de waffles got butter on um ! I'm mighty glad you-aU tuck a notion to go 'long. Look like dey ain't been no war when you kin git a tas'e er waffles. Git up dar, boss! what you holdin' back on level groun' fer, when you know I 'm .up here eatin' waffles? Ef anybody ax you-all how come I don't b'long ter no church, you up an' tell um dat it 's des kaze I ain't hear none er de preachers say dey gwinter be waffles up dar whar good folks goes. Ef dey 'U des say ' waffles/ I 'm wid um, an' I '11 stay wid um, too ; don't you disremember dat —
  ' Fer John-nee Bapiter is my name —

speaker: Johnny Bapter

utterance: Ketched him out ! I allowed maybe that was the way of it. Well, you an' your little Sis is mighty lucky chaps.

utterance: Drusilla was with us.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: The nigger gal ? H'm — well, yes — I reckon so. Well, maybe white folk '11 have a breathin' spell now that the whole kit and bilin' is free.

utterance: What has become of Little Mr^ Thimblefinger? I asked Aaron, but he only shook his head.

utterance: He ain't no nigger, I '11 be boun'.

utterance: Not the smartest man in the world.

utterance: Well, anyhow, you 've got the idee strong in your mind that he 's a heap the smartest man any where in these diggin's : now, hain't you ?

You've got the idee, an' your Sis, too, I reckon, that Aaron knows it all. Ef you 'U call her out, I '11 show you that Aaron don't know more than half of the things that mought be know'd.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: He 's going to show us something.

utterance: I reckon you '11 work now, plague on you !

utterance: Well, when folks do somethin' new an' quare, they allers fly back to conjuration to account fer it.

utterance: I don't keer where they fly, so long as they don't fly at me.

utterance: You see dat, don't you ?
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: 'T ain't the best I can do. I 'd have to make a dozen or more before I got my hand in. But this un is good enough. Ef you find anybody 'round here what can build a bubble that won't bust ner float off, why, jest ax 'em to do it, that 's all. No, that ain't all, nuther.
speaker: Mr. Bobs
addressee: Sweetest Susan, Buster John, and Drusilla

utterance: Ef you could hear brass bands a-playin', dis would n't lack much er bein' a whole circus.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: I 'm jest a-feelin' 'round fer to find whar the door is.
speaker: Mr. Bobs
addressee: Sweetest Susan, Buster John, and Drusilla

utterance: Come on, jump right in.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: Now, then, come on, an' in wi' you ! There, plunge right in !
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: Is it going to fly away with us, Mr. Bobs ?
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Why, what idees you 've got, honey ! How can a bubble fly away wi' you children on the inside ? You might as well ax me ef a crow can fly away wi' a bale of cotton.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: But this bubble is different from other bub bles.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: It is ; it shore is, fer I made it myself. But in wi' you ; don't let your buddy git lonesome.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: Come on, ef you 're a-comin'.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: I ain't bleedge ter go in dar, is I?
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Go in, or stay out j it 's all one to me. Come ! Talk out ! Which is it ? It '11 do you no good to go in, ner no harm, nuther.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: I don't want none er dat ar soap-suds ter git in my eyes.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Shet your eyes, then.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: I did n't know I wuz sech a mighty jumper
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: I know whar we at. dish yer place is whar dey make rainbows. You kin see um plattin' um now.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance:
I done tol' you-all 'bout puttin' yo' heads in all kinder holes an'
 traps. You may call dis a bubble ef you wanter ; but 't ain't no mo' a bubble dan I 'm a bubble. Look over yo'
 head ; does you see any bubble-skin, er frame, er hide, er whatsomever you may call it ? No, you don't. 'Stidder dat, you see two suns a-shinin'.
 I done promise myse'f when we went und' dat spring dat I wa'n't gwine ter let you drag me in no mo' places. An' yit, here I is ! You done drag me in here, an' now you got ter drag me out — ef I ever is ter git out.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Why, there 's nothing to do but to break the bubble.
speaker: Buster John

utterance:
Show me whar dey 's any bubble. You don't see none, an' I don't see none.
 We 're in a rainbow fact'ry, an' we better git out fo' it thunders.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: We 're gone now ! We done stirred um up. We better make a break an' git out er here 'fo' dey jump on us an' git us down.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance:
If you stay awake while you sleep,
  You will find that the whole is n't half:  You will find it is funny to weep,  And awfully solemn to laugh.

  Oh, hear our cause of complaint —  It 't is, it 't was, and it 't ain't !
speaker: little woman
addressee: Buster John, Drusilla, and Sweetest Susan

utterance: I tell you dey got us ! Dey ain't no sense in what dey singin'. Dey er all ravin' crazy. Look at um, how dey waggle der heads an' wobble 'bout when dey walk ! Dey sho is got us !
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: You don't seem to know me.
speaker: little woman
addressee: Buster John, Drusilla, and Sweetest Susan

utterance: No, we don't. Who are you ?
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: I 'm the Queen of Dreams
speaker: Queen of Dreams

utterance: Are we dreaming now?
speaker: Buster John

utterance: How could that be? You are not asleep ; and we are only here because of a hideous noise we heard. We were asleep. Do you think we should be dis turbed in our own kingdom ? We can't help our selves at this moment, but do you think it is right to invade our territory ?
speaker: Queen of Dreams

utterance: What she talkin' 'bout ? Who been 'vadin' any ter'ytory ?
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Why, Mr. Bobs made this bubble for us
speaker: Buster John

utterance: What is a bubble ?
speaker: Queen of Dreams

utterance: Why, a bubble — a bubble is — well, a bubble is a piece of soap-suds into which air has been blown
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: How big a piece, and how much air is neces sary to make a bubble ?
speaker: Queen of Dreams

utterance: I 'm sure I don't know. Bubbles are of all sizes ; but this one is the largest I ever saw.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: Which one ?
speaker: Queen of Dreams

utterance: The bubble we are in now
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance: I done tol' you we ain't got no business in here — ef we is in here. Dem ar creeturs '11 sho do us
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: It 's nobody but poor old Nightmare. He was out all last night, and worked hard at his business. He should be resting now, but the poor thing gets lonely when he opens one eye and finds us gone. He 's a great pet of mine. Come, tickle his ear, and see him open his mouth and growl.
speaker: Queen of Dreams
addressee: Buster John, Drusilla, and Sweetest Susan

utterance: I clean forgot to tell you not to stay in there too long. Folks must have fresh air, and you can't git that in a bubble. But ef you say the word, I '11 blow you up a bigger one, and you can stay in it longer.
speaker: Mr. Bobs
addressee: Buster John, Drusilla, and Sweetest Susan

utterance: You better le' me make you a good big un. I 'most know the nigger gal there would like to git in a great big un.
speaker: Mr. Bobs
addressee: Buster John, Drusilla, and Sweetest Susan

utterance: Humph ! You don't know me, den. Dem what likes bubbles can git in um an' stay in urn fer what I keer. AU I 'm skeered un is dat I '11 git in um in my dreams. Ef I does, eve'y hair in my haid '11 be gray de nex' time you see me.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Why, what in the world !
speaker: Miss Elviry

utterance: I 'm jest laughin' at that gal there. She went into the bubble along wi' the others.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: Why will you go on that away ? An' at your age, too. It 's a plum' shame !
speaker: Miss Elviry

utterance: Why, Elviry, ten year from now these young sters would n't take a hundred dollars for what they 've saw to-day.
speaker: Mr. Bobs

utterance: Ef you want me ter go, you better gi' me a bottle er some kinder med'cine, kaze ef I meet dat Thing out dar, I '11 have ten fits 'fo' you kin ax me what de matter.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Ef dat ol' white man '11 gi' me sump'n dat 'U wipe all dat out 'n my min' an' make me fergit 'bout him an' his bubble, I '11 say anywhar dat he de smartest man in de worl' ; but whar is dey any smartness in skeerin' chillun out'n der growth ? Ez I is now, des so you '11 see me when I 'm seventy year ol'. Ef gittin' skeer'd '11 stunt folks, den I 'm done stunted, an' stunted bad.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Maybe we were dreaming
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance:
Dream nothin' ! How kin folks stan' flat-footed in de broad open day light, an' have 'zactly de same dream ? Nobody ain't never see no creetur like dat, in no dream, kaze ef dey did, folks ud set up an' hire some
  body fer ter keep um 'wake. You-all do mighty funny. Wuz you too skeered ter look at de cree tur ? Here 's what uz des skeer'd 'nough ter look at it good. You call dat dreamin', does you?
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Uncle Fountain, they say there 's going to be a big fox hunt here Christmas week.
speaker: Buster John

utterance:
I hear um sesso. Well, let um hunt ef dey will; I done had my day at dat, I 'speck. Dey use ter hunt fum here a right smart; an' when dey got in de notion, nobody could n't do nothin' fer um but Fountain. 'T wuz ' Fountain ' here and ' Fountain ' dar, twel some er de quality, new ter de place, would up an' ax

ef all de niggers on de plantation is name Foun tain. Yes — yes, suh — I see myse'f now havin'
 de mommuck made fer de dogs, corn meal stewed thick, wid a han'ful er cracklin's flung in ; an'
 den de nex' mornin', 'fo' day, de cry would be fer Fountain ; an' nothin' would do, but Fountain mus' straddle a mule — ol' Puss, de pacin' mule — an' go 'long wid um. I had lim's in dem days, an' lungs, ef you '11 believe me. Yes — yes, suh — I wuz soople fum de word go — work all day, an' frolic all night.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Dat 's so
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: I 'member one time dat I went 'long fer ter look atter de Little Marster
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Now, dar wuz a chap fer you ! Dey say he died kaze he wuz puny ; but don't you b'lieve it ; he died kaze his heart an' his head wuz too big. Dey tuck in all dat he yever seed, er heard, er dre'mpt 'bout. No human bein' could go thoo life wid dat kinder head an' heart ; it 's agin' natur'.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Dat 's de Lord's trufe !
speaker: Big Sal

utterance:
Yes — yes, suh — I 'member de time des ez well es ef 't wuz yistiddy, maybe better. We put out, we did, 'bout light ; an' 'f o' we went a mile up jumped a gray — de reds had n't come in den — an' here dey had it 'roun' an' 'roun' same ez chasin' a rabbit. I wuz ter take keer er de Little Marster, but bless yo' soid ! he ain't gi' me time ter do dat. I allers shill b'lieve dat him an' dat gray pony had some deep pardnership wid one anudder, bekaze ef it hadn't been fer dat, de Little Marster would 'a' been drug out de saddle whilst dey runnin" thoo de scrub pines an' de black jacks. Dey went skeetin' here an' dar, an'
when de dogs ketched, dar wuz de Little Marster, an' de pony, right in 'mongst um. Hit 's so, ez sho ez I 'm a-settin' here.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance:
I 'speck my blood '11 be bet up ef I hear de horn a-blowin' and de dogs a-yelpin', but I 'm lots too old fer dem kinder doin's. Let um call on Johnny Bapter. He may not be so mighty knowin', but

he 's young and soople. But in times now gone, mo' speshually when de reds come in an' driv' de grays out, I know'd de feedin' groun' an' de promenade of all de foxes f um here ter de river — eve'y one un um. An' mo' dan dat, I know whar one ol' red stays right now. He 's ez big ez a cur dog. Folks tried de'r level bes' fer ter ketch dat ol' fox 'fo' de war. Dey brung dogs here fum away off yan', but he des played wid um. He kin tell a houn' fum a house dog by de bark, an' time he hear one atter midnight, he done gone — he done iip an' gone ! He got a white patch 'twixt his eyes, an' on 'count er dat, day call 'im Scour-Face.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Scar-Face. Why, he 's the fox they are going to catch !
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Oh, dey er gwine ter ketch 'im? Well, atter he's cotch, I hope dey 'U show im ter me. Scour-Face, er Scyar Face, I wanter see what dat white mark is 'twixt his eyes.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: They are going to bring Birdsong dogs
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Well, dey '11 hatter sing bird song er some yuther kinder song 'fo' dey ketch dat fox.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Besides all the other dogs, Joe Maxwell is to bring Hodo
speaker: Buster John

utterance:
I hear tell er dat dog. Dey say he sho is a mover. But, shucks ! you kin hear dat kinder talk about mos' any dog. But dish yer Hoodo got ter have brains ez well as legs ef he ketch ol' Scour-Face. I 'm a-talkin'
now, sho.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Where does old Scar-Face stay. Uncle Foun tain ?
speaker: Buster John

utterance:
You know dat ar broom-sage fiel' right up yan', cross de road f um de gin-house ? Well, he stay right dar. Ef you wuz ter go out er de door dar an' holler right loud, he 'd hear you, less'n he 's promenadin' some'rs else. He been dar dis long time. Dey don't a week pass but what I sees him slippin' an' slidin' 'long. He moves des like a shadder ; once an' awhile he '11 stop an'
look at you, but mos' er de time it 's f wifE ! an' he done gone. He got sense same ez folks.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: keep on f oolin' 'roun' an' gwine whar dey got no business twel some kind er cree tur would snap um up, an' walk off wid uml
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: We are hunting foxes on a new plan
speaker: Buster John

utterance:
If 't was me, I 'd find out the day the dogs come, and then I 'd pack my wallet, and take my walking-stick, and move into the middle of the big swamp.
 But he won't do it. He don't like the swamp; too much water, maybe, or maybe too much coon. I '11 give him fair warning.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Come in, you two boys
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: Here 's a comfortable chair by me — shall I  call you Mr. Maxwell ? I used to call you Joe  when you were younger.
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: Everybody calls me Joe. I  have come to ask you a favor. Will you allow  Buster John to go hunting with us to-morrow  morning?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Why, who ever heard of such a thing !
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: Mr. Dennis, there, has heard of it — twice.
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: How would he go ?
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: On my horse, behind me.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: What do you think of it, father ?
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: Why, I think he will be perfectly safe with Joe.
speaker: Mr. Dennis

utterance: Let him go, by all means. It will help to make a man of him.
speaker: Mr. Dennis

utterance: But two on a horse in a fox chase ! Why, it 's ridiculous. The horse would break down in half an hour.
speaker: Mrs. Wyche

utterance: How much does Buster John weigh ?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Fifty-five.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Then the horse would carry a hundred and forty pounds. Mr. Dennis weighs at least thirty pounds more than that, and he 's the smallest man in the party.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Where 's this famous fox-hunter who was to  go along and take care of me this morning ? The  horses are all ready, breakfast is ready (so Jemimy  says), and everybody is ready except the Great  North American Fox-Hunter, known far and wide as Buster John. What can be the matter with  him?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Don't wake the house, my son. There 's your overcoat your  mother sent up last night ; the air is chilly  this morning. There was a cold rain during the  night.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: But you have no overcoat.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Oh, I 'm tough. I ' ve  been out to look after my horse and dog. They  are both prime, and the weather is prime. If the  fox we are going after is a friend of yours, you  may as well bid him good-by this morning.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: He 's very cunning. A great many dogs have chased him. He is  called Scar-Face.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: I 've heard of him many a time. That 's the reason I 'm here to-day. If he's in the neighborhood this morning, and  you get a good chance, tell him good-by.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: I think he knows all about this hunt
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Oh, does he ? Well, it will be a mighty good  thing for him if he has moved his quarters ; but  we '11 beat around and about, and see if he won't  give us a dare.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: I know where he used to stay. He didn't know whether he was doing  right or wrong. Aaron showed me.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Aaron? Well, Aaron knows all about it,  and he knows a good deal more than that. Some  of these days I 'm going to write a book about  Aaron.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Sure enough ! I can  tell you lots of things to put in it. I can tell you  things that nobody would believe if they had n't  seen 'em.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Well, I '11 tell you what we '11 do. We '11 make a bargain : you shall  tail the fox to-day if you'll tell me all about  Aaron.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: That 's a fox as sure as the world.
speaker: Mr. Collingsworth

utterance: Pooh ! you 've been training your dogs with a cat skin. Call the silly creature off, or you wiU have the  whole pack going at full cry after a neighborhood  tomcat.
speaker: Mr. Dennis

utterance: What  did I tell you ?
speaker: Mr. Dennis

utterance: If there 's a fox  within a radius of five miles, this chase of a tom cat will scare him out of the country.
speaker: Mr. Dennis

utterance: Wait! I hear  Whalebone trying to whimper, and I know  mighty well he 's not interested in cats.
speaker: Mr. Kirkpatrick

utterance: If that fox was fool enough to go down to  the barn during the night, he 's fool enough to  stay in this field until he heard Music bark a  while ago. If that 's so, he '11 never run ahead  of the dogs any more.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: When he's up, where does he run?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Straight to'rds de p'int er woods 'cross yan der, an' den he b'ars ter de lef — allers ter de  lef.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Name er de Lord ! Look at dat dog !
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: Great goodness ! he must have stopped to catch a rat. What is he thinking about ? He won't last forty minutes.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Why, he 's a mile or more ahead of the  dogs.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: A mile and a quarter. Wait till  I send word to Hodo.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: They '11 not be far away when the end  comes. And if that old fox has  any grit in him, he '11 be caught somewhere be tween this hill and the point of woods the dogs  came out of.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Why, he 's running away from here.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Of course, and before  many minutes have passed, he '11 discover that  he can't play the old game. But if this is n't the  old fox we 're after, we '11 never see the dogs  catch him. They '11 be coming back presently,  and we '11 have to see if there 's any hair between  their teeth. If it is the old fox, he '11 run away  till he hears Hodo close at hand, and then he '11  get scared and try to reach home again.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: The rest are following the dogs.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: And you are sorry you 're not with 'em ?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Well, they 11 see no  more of the race than we have seen, even if we 're  after the wrong fox. If we are after the right  one, we 'U probably have him ready for their  inspection by the time they get back. But we 're  not going to stand here. We are going to gallop over there and be ready  to put Hodo right at his heels when he comes  back.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: That 's the right fox, and he 's pretty game, or he would have made  his double before this.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: If he had had an hour's start, this would have been a pretty performance, but  he 's had his work cut out for him this morning. Maybe he was making one of his loops beyond  the point of woods yonder. Yes, sir ! That 's  just what he was up to ! The dogs came out of  the woods not twenty-five yards from where they  went in.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Suppose the dogs have caught him ?
speaker: Buster John

utterance: No ; they 're coming back.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: I don't hear them.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Nor I, but Butterfly  does.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: He 's due here pretty soon, if he 's on sche dule time. Keep perfectly stUl. Don't move. I want you  to see how Hodo manages this sort of thing.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Yonder he comes.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: I give him five more minutes, but he 's certainly a game old fox.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Why, the other dogs were not in sight when  Hodo and the fox came into the field, and they  did n't come up tUl the fox was caught and  killed.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: Abercrombie, make the boy tell  you to-night how much Maxwell gave him to talk  that way.
speaker: Mr. Collingsworth

utterance: They 're  only joking. They know very  well that their dogs could never have caught this  fox.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Why, Hodo was running him all around here  like a rabbit before the rest of the dogs were in  sight, and before they did get in sight he had  killed him.
speaker: Buster John

utterance: I believe you. That dog of yours is a freak, Maxwell ; there '11  never be another like him. We'll have dogs  that can catch red foxes — this pack here can do  it any day in the week ; but we 'U never see  another dog with the ' go ' in him that your dog 's  got. Why, he 's venomous. Back yonder he  crashed through a briar patch just like he 'd been  shot out of a cannon, and his nose — well, he  does n't have to run on the drag at all, much  less put his head to the ground. I never saw  anything like it in my life. There ain't a fox in  the world that can stand up before him fifty  minutes. Look at him ! The other dogs are  tired out, and he 's walking around as fresh as a  daisy. No, sir ! we '11 never see his like again.
speaker: Mr. Collingsworth

utterance: What 's your opinion. Fountain ?
speaker: the White -Haired Master

utterance: Well, suh, I has seed  dogs in my time; I has seed dem what dey said  could run, an' I has seed dem what I b'lieved  could run, but not befo' dis day has deze eyes seed a dog what could reely run. Onless, suh, 'twuz dem ar greyhoun's what b'long ter Mars  Billy Ross. Dem dogs has got de body an' de  legs, but dey ain't got de head an' de win' er dish  yer Hodo. Give um a mile dash in open groun' an' maybe dey could git dar 'fo' dish yer dog,  but when it come ter brush an' briar and cane brake, dey would n't show up nowhar close ter  dat dog dar. Yes — yes, sub ! — e£ you 'd 'a' seed what I seed, you 'd 'a' rubbed yo' eyes like  I did.
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: What did you see. Fountain ?
speaker: the White -Haired Master

utterance: Well, suh, a bre£E of win' will tell it, but a  preacher would n't make you b'lieve it. When ol' Scour-Face made his turn fer ter come  back, he made it like a mule shoe — a wide sweep  at de top, but narrer, as you may say, at de heels. De top er de turn mought 'a' been a mile broad  — you-all may know better 'bout dat dan me —  but at de narrer part a man stan'in' in de middle  could 'a' seed de dogs gwine, an' could 'a' seed um  comin'. I know, bekaze I seed whar dey went down a gully, an' I wuz settin' on dish yer mule  in sight er de gully when I hear dat ar dog  fetchin' ol' Scour-Face back. De fox, suh, come by me not twenty yards  off, an' by de time he make his disappearance I  hear dat dog open up not a hunderd yards behin',  an' he come by me, suh, des like a bird a-flyin'. I fetched a whoop or two — you know how I kin  holler, suh — an' de dog tuck a seven-rail fence  an' never tetched it ; no, suh, he never tetched it. You '11 not b'lieve it, suh, an' I don't blame you ;  but I kin show you whar de dog riz, an' whar he  lit. You won't skacely b'lieve de tale yo' eyes '11  tell you when you see it ; but dar 's de signs, suh,  printed, as you may say, in de groun'. I fully  'spected he 'd ketch de fox right den an' dar ; but  ol' Scour-Face wuz a terror, suh, when it come  ter gittin' over groun'. But dat dog — you may  look at 'im yo'se'f, suh ; all de rest pantin' fit ter  kill, an' layin' down, an' him paradin' roun' here,  smellin' de bushes an' lookin' like he ain't been in  no chase. I said den, when he flung hisse'f over  de fence, ' I '11 look at you right close de fust  chance I git, kaze dey ain't no mo' like you, an' never is ter be !
speaker: Old Fountain

utterance: I 'm glad dey cotch 'im. De dogs done 'im des like he done de yuther creeturs. An' 'pon top er dat, he sot up dar an' grin an' brag 'bout how he gwine ter outdo um. I hear ol' folks say dat dem what do de mos' braggin' is de mos' no 'count. I 'm glad dey got 'im. He had plenty time ter go 'way; he des hung 'roun' here kaze he b'lieve dey ain't no dog kin outdo 'im.
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: You see dem peach blooms? Well, ol' Jack Frost kin come an' nip um, but when you see an' hear de mockin'-bird singin' while he flyin', you kin go on an' plant yo' corn an' cotton, kaze dey ain't gwine be no mo' fros' dat season.
speaker: Johnny Bapter

utterance: to be called for
speaker: narrator

utterance: You-aU say you want me ter go dar whar dat ol' man live at? I tell you right now I ain't achin' ter go dar, kaze I don't like de way he look out'n de eye ; he chug full er rank venom. But ef I does go, I ain't gwine ter follow atter you in no foolishness. I ain't gwine in no bubble,I ain't gwine in no Fimblethinger doin's,an' I ain't gwine nowhere ner do nothin' dat folks don't do when dey got der sevm senses
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: All dat, don't hender you-all frum gwine whar you choosen ter go. Ef you wanter git in bubbles an' git flew'd away wid, go an' git in 'um. Ef you wanter jump in springs an' pen's an' dream youer some'rs else, go ahead an' do it. utterance:
Not so very long ago, I went home before the shine-ball came out,  and there I found a big black snake curled up in  my bed. He raised his head and made his tongue  quiver, and I was afraid to go in. I did n't know  what to do. I knew if the shine-ball came out  and found me away from home that I would n't  be able to see what was going on, for the shine baU is so bright that it hurts my eyes.

 I wandered about among the trees, jumping  from one to the other, until finally I remembered  where a woodpecker had had a nest in a big pine  not far off. I had seen him hiding some acorns  there, and at night I used to go there and see  how they tasted, and I thought if I could get  there by the time the shine-baU came out I could  get a little rest. Well, I went to the pine and crawled into the woodpecker's nest. But it was  very uncomfortable, and had a bad smell. There  was no soft bed in it, such as I had at home, and  everything about it was rough. The door —
Now I don't think you ought to eat all the good  ones yourself and pick out the bad ones for me.
 Why, that last piece was black on one side.
speaker: Flit

utterance: There — now that 's better. The door of the woodpecker's  house looked towards the place where the shine ball comes from, and everything about it seemed  to be wrong. But it was the best I could do. I  crept in and curled up for such sleep as I could  get in such a place. I went to sleep, too, for I  was very tired. How long I slept I don't know,  but when I woke I was hot. The shine-ball was  looking right in the door, and I was nearly suffo cated.
speaker: Flit

utterance: What de name er goodness is de shine-ball ?
speaker: Drusilla

utterance: Why, it 's the sun, goosey.
speaker: Sweetest Susan

utterance:
I could n't see very well, and  so I went on top of the limb again ; but I had  hardly stretched out there, thinking the hawk  was gone, when I felt the wind again, and this  time she did n't miss me more than the width of  one of my whiskers. Up went the hawk again,  and I thought it would be best for me to stay  under the limb. But this did n't help me much.
 The hawk began to call her mate, and in a very  short time there were two of them sailing around.
 The biggest one came slowly down and lit on the  limb right over me. She leaned forward and  looked at me ; and of all the horrible creatures  you ever saw, she was the most horrible. She  breathed as loud as a 'possum snores.

 I came very near dropping from the limb. I  moved toward the body of the tree, and the  hawk moved after me and tried to reach me with  her hooked beak. I made a dash and went round  the body of the tree, and as I did so the hawk's  mate came swooping down. By this time the  other hawk was on the wing, and by the time I  darted on the other side she was ready to swoop.
 This would n't have lasted long. Some one came  along and said ' shoo ' to the hawks, and they flew  away, and then I felt that same somebody take  me from the tree more dead than alive.
speaker: Flit
